objects.blurb: L.W. Molnar & Associates is closing in on its plan to begin construction on the first of three new office buildings totaling more than 500,000 square feet of space amid public plazas along with a hotel, restaurants and shops on land it owns at the Oakland portal site, a key yet sloped parcel of property between Fifth and Forbes Avenues ...
objects.title: Molnar details Oakland portal plans to come

objects.blurb: Show-and-Tell is not just for kindergarten anymore. It's a concept even a Ph.D. can grasp. This evening Project Olympus, the Carnegie Mellon University incubator for companies in the embryonic stage, is showing off some of the latest ideas to come out of the former horse stable that houses the program. One of the promising ideas to be featured is a ...
objects.title: Foot-powered phone charger among Project Olympus innovations

objects.blurb: A judge has blocked the state from discounting ballots cast next month by voters who lack the photo identification required under the new voter ID law. Voters will be asked for their identification at the polls, but will vote by normal procedures and their vote will count regardless of whether they have an ID, according to officials on both sides ...
objects.title: Judge issues partial injunction of state's Voter ID law

objects.blurb: You’ve worked diligently to make sure your voice was heard. Now you can see the fruits of your labor. The Oakland 2025 Master Plan: A Vision for Sustainable Living and Mobility is complete, and it’s live on our website for you to read and share with your neighbors and colleagues. The document outlines strategies that will guide and support Oakland’s ...
objects.title: Oakland 2025 is Complete!

objects.blurb: On a 5-4 vote, the Pittsburgh Public Schools board Wednesday decided to put the former Schenley High School in Oakland up for sale. The board voted to seek bids on the historic building that was closed in 2008 after then-superintendent Mark Roosevelt said it would take $76.2 million to renovate, including addressing an asbestos problem. It was built in 1916. ...
objects.title: Schenley High in Pittsburgh put up for sale

objects.blurb: Of all of the communities where UPMC has a presence, none has felt the impact of the region's largest employer and dominant health care provider like Pittsburgh's Oakland neighborhood. Not only was Oakland the birthplace of UPMC, it was the health care system's focus for most of the last 30 years, where its headquarters and most of its employees were ...
objects.title: UPMC leaves huge impression on Oakland

objects.blurb: Twenty-one years after it all came down, state Sen. Jim Ferlo still hears the song every time he passes the Oakland site. "As Joni Mitchell would say, 'They paved over paradise and put up a parking lot.' " To the Highland Park Democrat and other Pittsburgh preservationists, "paradise" in this case was the Syria Mosque concert hall, a 3,700-seat, ornate, ...
objects.title: Two decades later, razing of Syria Mosque still a sore topic

objects.blurb: Construction could begin next year on an Oakland development six years in the making that would provide office space, apartments and a hotel. The Oakland Portal, announced in 2006, awaits final approvals from the Pittsburgh Zoning Board of Adjustment and the city Planning Commission, said Lou Molnar, whose L.W. Molnar Associates is the developer. People can inspect the plan at ...
objects.title: Long-delayed project in Oakland takes step closer to construction

objects.blurb: The University of Pittsburgh said Wednesday it is joining a roster of universities that have begun making available free interactive course materials to millions of online learners. Pitt is among 32 schools that have formed partnerships with Coursera, whose roster of schools worldwide includes a number of Ivy League institutions as well as other prominent public and private campuses. Through ...
objects.title: Pitt to offer free interactive course materials

objects.blurb: Teens soon won’t go to the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh just to peruse the works of others. Instead, they’ll go to create their own works — everything from CDs to movies. The library system is holding a party from 5 to 8 p.m. Wednesday at the main branch in Oakland to celebrate its four teen labs. The labs — in ...
objects.title: Carnegie libraries to tap into teen creativity

objects.blurb: For the upcoming election, a new Pennsylvania law passed in early August requires that all voters, including students, must present some form of government-issued photo identification at the polls. The Voter ID Law specifies that the identification used must have a picture and an expiration date. As Carnegie Mellon student IDs have both already, students are allowed to use their ...
objects.title: Pennsylvania’s new voter ID law could stump students

objects.blurb: Jonathan Young, chairman of the National Council on Disability, is this year's lecturer for the Oct. 4 Thornburgh Family Lecture Series on Disability Law and Policy at the University of Pittsburgh. The lecture, "Beyond Budgets: From Policy to Progress in Disability Employment," will be held at 1 p.m. at the University Club, Oakland. Mr. Young was appointed chairman by President ...
objects.title: National disability leader to lecture Oct. 4 at Pitt

objects.blurb: At Carlow University, an Oakland college with mostly female students, taking a course in women's studies is a requirement for graduation. "It fits in with the legacy of the school," said Katie Hogan, director of the women's studies program at the school, which was founded in 1929 by the Catholic Sisters of Mercy. The school's founders, she said, were interested ...
objects.title: Carlow University Women's Studies marks 40 years

objects.blurb: Heading into Pitt's matchup against Virginia Tech at Heinz Field this afternoon, few gave the Panthers a chance against the No. 13 Hokies. But Pitt put together its most complete performance of the season and took advantage of several Virginia Tech mistakes in a 35-17 upset victory. The Panthers (1-2) jumped out to a 14-0 first-quarter lead and continued to ...
objects.title: Pitt stuns Virginia Tech, 35-17

objects.blurb: On Friday, Carnegie Museum of Art in Oakland opens its newly reinstalled galleries of 19th-century American and European art, showing a shift in the way these works are presented. “Each collection — great and small — gives us a part of the larger history of art, and tells the unique story of its own development,” Lynn Zelevansky, the director of ...
objects.title: Carnegie will unveil reinstalled art galleries

objects.blurb: Summer may historically be considered concert season, but some of this year's biggest tours are poised to hit town this fall. Meanwhile, the series we've come to expect (VIA, the Warhol's Sound Series) return with heavy-hitting lineups. For the rock traditionalist, a few major events are can't-miss. Neil Young and Crazy Horse play the Petersen Events Center on Oct. 9, ...
objects.title: Fall Arts Guide: Music

objects.blurb: Like a gleeful student showing off a good report card, the University of Pittsburgh has been eagerly sharing the results of its recent evaluation by the Middle States Commission on Higher Education. No wonder. The glowing report, laced with superlatives, is impartial evidence of further improvements made at Pitt since its positive review in 2002 and since 1996, when an ...
objects.title: Glowing report: Pitt earns an impartial review of superlatives

objects.blurb: On a recent, hot Friday afternoon members of the Platypus team were gathered around a pond in Schenley Park below the Carnegie Mellon University testing their technology. Platypus, a robotics company founded by six researchers at the CMU Robotics Institute, has developed a fully autonomous watercraft that they hope to introduce to various uses in environmental monitoring. “It’s a tool ...
objects.title: CMU startup adds robotics to water

objects.blurb: Neither Andrew Keleman nor Mike Rubino had ever made a film in 48 hours before. But in July, their smart detective spoof "Letter Die: A Gamut Sibling Mystery" was voted best film at Pittsburgh's incarnation of the national 48 Hour Film Project short-film contest. A screening highlights the Sept. 11 Film Kitchen. Keleman shoots and edits for a production house ...
objects.title: The winning entry for Pittsburgh 48 Hour Film Project headlines this month

objects.blurb: Port Authority of Allegheny County extended a ridership agreement with the University of Pittsburgh for another month while the parties continue negotiating a new long-term deal, officials said. Port Authority’s U-Pass program allows Pitt’s 40,000 students and employees with a valid, university-issued ID card to ride agency vehicles without paying fares. Pitt paid Port Authority $6.8 million in the last ...
objects.title: Pitt, Port Authority OK extension

objects.blurb: Nine-year-old Maia Beckerman spent Labor Day enjoying the last day of the swimming season in the Schenley Park pool with her mom and sister and working on her diving. “I can touch the bottom at 11 (feet). I’m still working on 12,” said Beckerman of Park Place, her goggles strapped on her head. “I might grow a foot by next ...
objects.title: Summer makes final splash as Western Pennsylvania pools look to close

objects.blurb: Behind a defensive unit unable to defend, Pitt lost its season opener to a Football Championship Subdivision opponent. The upset 31-17 loss to Youngstown State, which was first-year head coach Paul Chryst’s debut in charge of the Panthers, also marked the first time Pitt had ever lost to an FCS school. Early on, Pitt quarterback Tino Sunseri looked methodical and ...
objects.title: Loss starts off season under Chryst

objects.blurb: In the storied 122-year history of the Pitt football program, he is the first head coach to not have a vowel in his last name. But that’s where the fun facts end when it comes to Paul Chryst, the latest leader of Pitt football after the program’s second consecutive offseason of coaching turmoil. It didn’t take long for the new ...
objects.title: Football Preview: Chryst latest to lead Pitt football program

objects.blurb: Students and visitors planning to park on the streets of Oakland can leave their quarters at home without the fear of expired meters this Friday. The Public Parking Authority of Pittsburgh has partnered with Cale America Inc. to install a new pay-by-license parking meter system that replaces single-space meters with multi-space machines in the North Shore, Oakland, SouthSide Works, the ...
objects.title: New, cash-free parking meters to be rolled out in Oakland Friday

objects.blurb: An Ohio man has pleaded not guilty before a federal magistrate in Pittsburgh who arraigned him on a charge of conspiracy for allegedly claiming to be part of the computer hacking group "Anonymous" and posting a YouTube threat to release confidential computer information belonging to the University of Pittsburgh. Alexander Waterland, 24, of Loveland, appeared in court Tuesday. Federal authorities ...
objects.title: Man pleads not guilty to Pitt threat charges

objects.blurb: Geof Becker has run up against his share of nuisance properties during 20 years of living in South Oakland: rundown houses, overgrown yards, garbage-strewn porches and all-night parties. He’s taking an active role in combating a problem that afflicts almost every Pittsburgh neighborhood. Becker, 52, is co-chairman of Oakwatch, an Oakland-based volunteer group that works with the city in identifying ...
objects.title: Code enforcement makes better neighborhood, Oakland volunteer says  Read more: h

objects.blurb: When Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart called the pipe organ “the king of instruments” he was speaking from 14 years of first-hand experience. He began playing the instrument when he was 7 and continued to play pipe organs on his travels in Europe until at least 1789, two years before his death. Apart from earlier and smaller instruments in monasteries, somewhat larger ...
objects.title: Pipe organs essential part of Pittsburgh's big churches

objects.blurb: More than 3,000 black umbrellas dotted the green outside the University of Pittsburgh's Petersen Events Center Thursday even though it wasn't raining. Pitt's freshman class descended on the lawn, popped up umbrellas and performed a six-minute dance in unison -- both to break a world record and to honor dancer and actor Gene Kelly, a Pittsburgh native and 1933 Pitt ...
objects.title: Dancin' on the lawn: University of Pittsburgh freshmen set a world record

objects.blurb: A few weeks ago as I was walking down Forbes Avenue between Pitt and CMU, I was struck by an amazing scene. It was a beautiful summer day, the sun was out and a light breeze carried cool air along with the bustle of students from all over the world heading to summer classes. The Cathedral of Learning towered over ...
objects.title: 10 Things to Love about Oakland

objects.blurb: Jennifer Breslin's introduction to college was quick and simple. Her parents brought her to her dorm room, gave her a kiss and said goodbye. "That was it," she said. On Tuesday morning, it was her turn to be the parent dropping off the college student. And as she and her husband Joe arrived at Duquesne University with their 18-year-old daughter, ...
objects.title: Colleges' goal: No freshman will be disoriented

objects.blurb: While many of the details haven't been worked out, state and local officials said Tuesday that they have forged a long-term solution for chronic funding problems at the Port Authority. For transit riders and advocates, it was one of the better days in a long time as these events unfolded: • The authority board of directors approved a new contract ...
objects.title: $40 million in Pa. transit funding delivered

objects.blurb: Cutting a year from her undergraduate degree program will save Chatham University student Laura Ralich about $40,000, big money for any potentially debt-strapped collegian. Ralich, 22, of Aliquippa expects to graduate in spring from Chatham’s accelerated three-year program in interior architecture. She hopes to apply the time and money she saves toward a master’s degree in architecture. “You learn so ...
objects.title: Colleges cap tuition hikes to curb rising costs

objects.blurb: f nothing else, credit Pitt offensive line coach Jim Hueber for being honest. For pretty much all of training camp, his starting five has been the most consistent position unit on the team. Virtually every team drill has Cory King, Chris Jacobson, Ryan Turnley, Ryan Schlieper and Matt Rotheram with the first unit. Hueber would like to keep it that ...
objects.title: Pitt's offensive line provides upfront leadership

objects.blurb: The Port Authority board of directors is expected to vote this morning to approve a four-year contract with the agency's largest union and to rescind record-breaking service cuts and layoffs that were scheduled to take effect Sept. 2. The 10 a.m. special meeting follows overwhelming union approval of the contract, which has an estimated $60 million in wage and benefit ...
objects.title: Port Authority Transit board expected to OK contract, avoid cuts

objects.blurb: Adam Busby, the Dublin-based Scotsman charged with emailing 40 bomb threats targeting the University of Pittsburgh, is a publicity-obsessed narcissist who enjoys creating just the kind of fear and disruption that occurred at Pitt, according to a retired journalist in Scotland who has known him for more than two decades. Moreover, David Leslie of Glasgow said, the emailing of threats ...
objects.title: Pitt bomb threat suspect called publicity hound

objects.blurb: They’ve been vilified, cursed and even slapped around. In fact, since the world’s first coin-operated parking meters were installed in Oklahoma City in 1935, they’ve been the bane of drivers forced to rummage in the dark recesses of purses and under car seats for loose change to feed the ticking beasts. But the coin-eating, steel-gray units are disappearing from the ...
objects.title: Time’s up for nation’s coin-operated parking meters: Pittsburgh is going digital

objects.blurb: Move-in of residence hall students at Carnegie Mellon University Sunday and at the University of Pittsburgh beginning Tuesday has prompted both schools to issue traffic alerts regarding road closures. On Sunday, three Oakland streets next to Carnegie Mellon will be shut to through traffic from 6 a.m. to 4 p.m as 1,420 first-year students move their belongings onto campus for ...
objects.title: CMU, Pitt shut streets as students move in

objects.blurb: OAKLAND (KDKA) – It’s hard to believe, but it’s almost back to school time for college students. CMU and Pitt students are set to move-in beginning Sunday that will mean some traffic troubles in Oakland. In Oakland, it’s the calm before the storm. On Sunday, more than 1,400 first-year students will flood Carnegie Mellon University.
objects.title: Heavy Traffic In Oakland Expected As College Students Move In

objects.blurb: No one could have predicted that a quiet, bookish girl from Johnstown would turn to a life of crime, that she would immerse herself in the grubby underworld of black-market baby brokers, hit men, drug dealers and philandering politicians. Kathleen George told herself she was only slumming when she started to write her first whodunit. It would entail researching real-life ...
objects.title: Pitt professor’s latest book: Lawyers, affairs and murder

objects.blurb: A 64-year-old, wheelchair-using Scottish man from Dublin, who already has served a prison sentence for emailing hoax bomb threats, was indicted Wednesday as the person responsible for emailing a series of 40 false bomb threats targeting the University of Pittsburgh during the spring semester. A federal grand jury in Pittsburgh also charged the suspect, Adam Stuart Busby, with sending emailed ...
objects.title: Charges put a face to Pitt bomb threats

objects.blurb: In the spring, as dozens of bomb threats against University of Pittsburgh buildings forced students out of class and sometimes out of bed, speculation about who could be the hoaxer ran rampant. Theories sprang forth on blogs and online discussion forums: Could it be a current student? A former student with a grudge against the school? Or maybe a former ...
objects.title: Why Pitt? Even after arrest in bomb threats, students wonder

objects.blurb: Family House has a new natural gas powered shuttle, thanks to a grant from EQT Foundation. Family House is a nonprofit, Oakland-based agency that provides affordable housing and transportation for out-of-town families with loved ones in local hospitals. EQT Corp. (NYSE: EQT) is an integrated energy company with headquarters in downtown Pittsburgh.
objects.title: EQT funds new shuttle for Family House

objects.blurb: With globe-shaped lights, a gently undulating walkway and glittering glass sequins on the chain-link side walls, East Liberty's new pedestrian bridge is as much art as infrastructure. People talk about how it's "just not like any other bridge," David Serbin, chief financial officer for East Liberty Development Inc., said. Pittsburgh officials hope to encourage more of that kind of innovation ...
objects.title: Program designed to expand artwork through Pittsburgh

objects.blurb: National publications have identified Pittsburgh as America’s Most Livable City, and a new survey shows many people who live in the region agree. Residents of 32 counties in the four-state region around the city gave it outstanding marks for overall quality of life and their own happiness, according to the Pittsburgh Regional Quality of Life Survey that PittsburghToday and the ...
objects.title: Survey: Living in Pittsburgh is good

objects.blurb: Public transit cuts scheduled for September will cost the public far more than the $60 million that is needed to avert them, a community organization said today.
objects.title: Cut to public transit could cost more than budget gap

objects.blurb: The University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine stepped up training of next-generation plastic surgeons by starting a Department of Plastic Surgery, as top surgeons screen candidates for Pitt’s first face transplant.
objects.title: Pitt department to help advance next generation of plastic surgeons

objects.blurb: A tentative deal to avoid the largest-ever service cuts by the Pittsburgh area's transit agency depends on union concessions.
objects.title: Port Authority, governor, county, union working to avoid service cuts, layoffs

objects.blurb: Pittsburgh City Council approved legislation Monday that sets up a new round of contributions from a few dozen nonprofit groups, but did so only after a flurry of last-minute questions and complaints that hung up the deal for a couple of hours.
objects.title: City Council approves nonprofit contribution

objects.blurb: President Barack Obama on Friday will wrap up his two-day bus tour through Northern Ohio and Western Pennsylvania at Carnegie Mellon University. On CMU's College of Fine Arts lawn, Mr. Obama will talk about his efforts over the last three years to get the economy back on track.
objects.title: Tickets available today for President Obama's Friday visit to CMU

objects.blurb: Four University of Pittsburgh engineering students have earned their school a visit from the leader of Colbert Nation: Stephen Colbert. A few weeks back, Mr. Colbert announced on his late-night Comedy Central television show that he would be selling 1,000 "Colbert Super PAC Super Fun Pack" boxes, featuring a variety of silly, PAC-related merchandise and a treasure map. That map ...
objects.title: Pitt students win Colbert Report treasure hunt

objects.blurb: [Many] people assume the word is a corruption of "jack off." ... In fact, jagoff has its roots in the northern British Isles, "where most of the original English-speaking settlers in this area came from," says Carnegie Mellon University professor Barbara Johnstone, the foremost expert on local speech patterns. There, the verb "to jag" meant "to prick or poke" — ...
objects.title: Let us now praise famous jagoffs

objects.blurb: Working with promising startups like Optimus Technologies and eMetrics got MaryBeth Guzzetta of Idea Foundry to thinking. Pittsburgh is rich in opportunities for tech startups. Solid models exist to support them. But what about the growing number of for-profit companies that have, at their core, a more social mission?
objects.title: Idea Foundry launches InterSector, a new program for social enterprises

objects.blurb: Prosecutors and a defense attorney have asked the U.S. District Court to postpone a preliminary hearing in a criminal case against the man accused of threats and extortion against the University of Pittsburgh. Alexander Waterland, 24, of Loveland, Ohio, was scheduled to appear in the U.S. District Court, Downtown, today. His attorney, Anthony Bittner, and Assistant U.S. Attorney James T. ...
objects.title: Hearing postponed in Pitt threat case

objects.blurb: After two days of ThinkBike workshops, the City of Pittsburgh is ready to bring the highest level of bicycle infrastructure to Oakland. Based on the recommendations of Dutch mobility experts, the City is beginning the process of installing separated cycle tracks in the Fifth-Forbes corridor of this heavily trafficked neighborhood. According to the City's Bicycle and Pedestrian Coordinator Stephen Patchan, ...
objects.title: Dutch experts propose cycle tracks for Oakland

objects.blurb: Pittsburgh’s universities and ethnically-diverse neighborhoods are known for breeding creativity. These five writers made a name for themselves using their Pittsburgh neighborhood and university connections. Make these titles must reads on your summer book list.
objects.title: 5 Must-Read Books by Pittsburgh Authors

objects.blurb: Any organization receiving a break on Allegheny County real-estate taxes should be required to prove its tax-exempt status annually, county Controller Chelsa Wagner recommended today. Such a policy would help the county recoup a portion of $95 million in potential county property taxes that would otherwise be paid if their owners did not qualify for the exemptions, she said. "While ...
objects.title: County controller: County should check tax-exempt status annually

objects.blurb: The University of Pittsburgh has filed a motion to dismiss a recent complaint that claims the university discriminates against transgender students, calling it unsubstantiated. Pitt filed its response last week to the complaint filed April 25 with the Pittsburgh Commission on Human Relations by the Rainbow Alliance, an organization which advocates for what it describes as the interests of the ...
objects.title: Pitt denies discriminating against transgender students

objects.blurb: Residents of 30 voting districts in about 15 neighborhoods would receive new Pittsburgh City Council representation under a preliminary redistricting map to be released Monday. Redistricting occurs after the census every 10 years so the nine council districts have a roughly equal number of residents. Under the new map, each council district should represent about 34,000 residents. The process this ...
objects.title: Map plan changes council representation in 30 districts

objects.blurb: Eat’n Park wanted to try a new type of restaurant, something smaller than its traditional sit-down locations that would fit easily into an urban storefront. With help from Fathom, a Downtown innovation design and strategy company, an idea that started with the working name Project X evolved into Hello Bistro – set to open its first location on Thursday on ...
objects.title: Hello Bistro, Eat N Park spinoff, to open this Thursday

objects.blurb: Pittsburgh is going Dutch to improve conditions for bicyclists in Oakland. Transportation experts from the Netherlands will meet with city officials about increasing bicycle use in the Fifth-Forbes corridor during a workshop Thursday and Friday at Carnegie Mellon University. Recommendations from the experts will be released on Friday. “We have targeted the Oakland corridor as a key area that needs ...
objects.title: Dutch firm asked to help boost bicycle use in Oakland

objects.blurb: "Two and a Half Men" star Ashton Kutcher is among the investors in a Carnegie Mellon Univeristy start-up called Duolingo. Malia Spencer wrote about the language translation website in the June 1 edition of the Pittsburgh Business Times. Two weeks later, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette catches up to the story with the nugget that Duolingo's $3.3 million funding round includes money ...
objects.title: Kutcher invests in CMU start-up Duolingo

objects.blurb: More than 300 employees at the University of Pittsburgh have decided to take advantage of an early retirement incentive the university offered in April. But the retirements are not expected to affect classrooms or educational programs because no faculty are involved, said Pitt spokesman Robert Hill. A total of 672 "classified" employees are eligible for the early retirement offer, which ...
objects.title: 300-plus University of Pittsburgh employees opt for early retirement  Read more

objects.blurb: A series of bomb threats that evoked fear and disrupted college life for more than a month at the University of Pittsburgh ended April 21, but the search for the person or persons responsible has continued unabated. "We've actually increased our investigation," said Kelly Kochamba, a spokeswoman for the FBI in Pittsburgh. "It's ongoing, it's expanded and we're investigating a ...
objects.title: Probe into Pitt bomb threats continues, FBI says

objects.blurb: Janice and Chuck Hackett's son beat the odds. Born eight weeks early and weighing just 2 pounds 4 ounces, Cameron Hackett spent 75 days in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at Magee-Womens Hospital of UPMC. "The nurses at Magee and the doctors are why we have a family," Janice Hackett, 43, of Collier said on Sunday at the 10th annual ...
objects.title: Reunion joins families helped by Magee neonatal unit

objects.blurb: The University of Pittsburgh's Salk Hall, which houses its dental school, was evacuated this morning after a small fire was reported on the fourth floor there. The fire rose to a three-alarm, but no injuries were reported. Firefighters and the city's arson squad were called, per protocol, to the building on Terrace Street in Oakland about 11:30 a.m. The fire ...
objects.title: Small fire extinguished at Pitt's Salk Hall

objects.blurb: Today is the grand opening of the Phipps Center for Sustainable Landscapes (CSL), a building that promises to be one of the greenest in the world. The CSL is a research, education, and administrative complex, and meets the three highest green building standards: The Living Building Challenge; LEED Platinum; and the SITES landscape rating system. The complex is the centerpiece ...
objects.title: Phipps' Center for Sustainable Landscapes opens today, to be greenest building

objects.blurb: Passing by an Oakland restaurant recently where a local tech CEO was engaged in an intense business lunch with an executive from a major out-of-state venture capital firm, Innovation Works CEO Rich Lunak said he saw the future of the city's tech sector. And he believes the signs indicate that future is much closer than many, both in and out ...
objects.title: Pittsburgh-based Innovation Works living up to its name

objects.blurb: Though an agreement still hasn't been signed, the city expects to receive more than $3 million in contributions from nonprofit groups this year, Mayor Luke Ravenstahl's spokeswoman said Monday. Legislation that would establish a new two-year agreement with Pittsburgh Public Service Fund, a consortium of nonprofit groups, will be introduced in city council today. The legislation doesn't specify the amount ...
objects.title: Pittsburgh anticipating $3 million from nonprofits

objects.blurb: Contrary to popular belief, one of America’s most popular foods, the french fry, originated in Belgium and not in France. Variants of this favorite food are plentiful: thick-cut fries, steak fries, shoestring fries, crinkle fries, curly fries, hand-cut fries, tornado fries… Call them whatever you want – Americans scarf down heaping amounts, approximately 28 pounds per person per year. Pittsburghers ...
objects.title: Best French Fries In Pittsburgh

objects.blurb: Schenley Plaza in Oakland buzzed with activity Wednesday on opening day of the Pittsburgh International Children’s Festival. The biggest star is an inflatable sculpture in Bill Mazeroski field. There’s also sunflowers and giraffes, a duck-footed owl and Mr. McFeely. The International Children’s Festival is back and kids have more hands-on activities than ever. Festival Director Pam Lieberman says Oakland is ...
objects.title: Children’s Festival Has Schenley Plaza Buzzing With Activity

objects.blurb: When professor John Metzger began his tenure as director of Pitt’s nuclear engineering program in 2010, the certificate program focused primarily on academics, placing little emphasis on research. In the two years of his leadership, the nuclear engineering department considerably increased its propensity for research, increasing enrollment in its graduate program. Last week, Metzger’s work won Pitt grants totaling $1.3 ...
objects.title: Pitt awarded $1.3 million in grants for nuclear research

objects.blurb: Jeannie Horgan of Greenfield hasn't missed any of the 20 Komen Pittsburgh Races for the Cure. "I did all the Komens because my mom died of breast cancer when she was young," said Ms. Horgan, 58. But there was more to it than that. On Sunday, she wore the deep pink T-shirt given the survivors who paraded around Flagstaff Hill ...
objects.title: Pittsburgh Race for the Cure brings thousands together

objects.blurb: he University of Pittsburgh filed suit Friday against The Big East Conference in the Allegheny County Court of Common Pleas for allowing two members -- Texas Christian University and West Virginia University -- to withdraw early from the conference. Conference rules state that members must give 27 months of notice before leaving the league, but Big East officials allowed TCU ...
objects.title: Pitt files lawsuit against Big East

objects.blurb: One man remains hospitalized and another has been jailed after a robbery attempt sparked a shootout outside a McDonald's in Oakland early this morning. A 23-year-old Morningside man and his friend were leaving the McDonald's in the 3900 block of Forbes Avenue about 2:40 a.m. when another man pulled out a gun and tried to rob him of his bracelet, ...
objects.title: One to hospital, one to jail after failed robbery outside McDonald's in Oakland

objects.blurb: Carnegie Mellon University plans to pay the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh more than $5 million for a three-story building on a half-acre on Fifth Avenue. The Cardinal Dearden Center is one of five parcels totaling nearly 1 1/2 acres at the site that the diocese hopes to sell to CMU, substantially expanding the university's holdings in the heart of Oakland. ...
objects.title: CMU to pay $5 million for diocesan property

objects.blurb: The Republican-controlled Pennsylvania Senate Appropriations Committee voted unanimously on Tuesday to maintain Pitt’s state funding at $136.1 million for the next fiscal year, despite Gov. Tom Corbett’s proposed 30 percent cut. In February, Corbett proposed a 30 percent slash to three of the four state-related Universities — Pitt, Penn State and Temple. Lincoln, by far the smallest of the four ...
objects.title: Senate Appropriations Committee aims to restore Pitt funding

objects.blurb: Newlyweds Josh and Jessica Troiano ducked into First Presbyterian Church before dawn Sunday morning, the moon still hanging over Downtown, the streets still quiet. Within hours, a record 19,000 entrants would navigate the streets of Pittsburgh for the fourth running of the marathon since its rebirth in 2009. But for a moment, in the peaceful dark wooden pews, the Troianos ...
objects.title: 19,000 marathoners bear the heat

objects.blurb: City animal-control officers rescued seven ducklings Friday from a Bloomfield storm sewer but couldn't corral the mother after she flew away. Gerald Akrie, supervisor of animal care and control, said a bystander reported about 11:30 a.m. that the ducklings had fallen through a storm grate and that the mother sat down on the grate and refused to move. Mr. Akrie ...
objects.title: Officials rescue seven ducklings

objects.blurb: Trying to predict the weather in Pittsburgh four days in advance can be a fool's errand, but organizers for the Pittsburgh Marathon are optimistic for the race this weekend. Weather service forecasts issued Wednesday called for temperatures in the mid-50s at the start of the race in the morning, creeping up to the 70s by early afternoon, with a high ...
objects.title: Sunny outlook for Pittsburgh Marathon runners this weekend

objects.blurb: Major upgrades under way for more than a decade at VA Pittsburgh Healthcare System facilities are moving forward with the completion of a $75.8 million Consolidation Building on Oakland's University Drive campus. The building, situated at Brackenridge and Allequippa streets, represents "the new standard in comprehensive, veteran-focused care," according to VA Pittsburgh officials. Key advances include 78 secure, private beds ...
objects.title: VA to open new Oakland facility

objects.blurb: First there were bomb threats. Now there is a YouTube threat. A group using the name “Anonymous” claims in an April 26 YouTube video that it has hacked into Pitt’s computer system and downloaded personal information about Pitt students, employees and alumni. The group, which used a synthesized voice to deliver its message, claims to have taken more than 200 ...
objects.title: Anonymous group claims it hacked Pitt’s computer system

objects.blurb: Many of us have emotional ties to our neighborhoods and know the boundaries, but what do those boundaries really mean to us? They were fixed by historical use, geography, roadways, built barriers and urban planning. They are really fairly meaningless, and we prove that by crossing them frequently and regularly to do things we need and want to do. Computer ...
objects.title: City Walkabout / Livehoods.orgs maps a different view of our neighborhoods

objects.blurb: For Iryna Zenyuk, chess is taking a back seat these days to a Ph.D. in mechanical engineering at Carnegie Mellon. But even in this relatively relaxed period, she's still one of the 10 best female chess players in the country. And next week, the 25-year-old Squirrel Hill resident will travel to the U.S. Women's Championship chess tournament in St. Louis ...
objects.title: CMU student aims for top chess honors

objects.blurb: A new trailer for "The Dark Knight Rises" is, if possible, even bleaker than the previous ones. The clips from the movie, which was partly filmed in Pittsburgh, depict a broken down Bruce Wayne (Christian Bale) being held captive by Bane (Tom Hardy). It's a little easier to understand the muzzled Bane in this trailer as he tells Wayne, "I'm ...
objects.title: New 'Dark Knight Rises' trailer hits Web

objects.blurb: Getting around Pittsburgh may get a lot harder next fall. The Port Authority of Allegheny County, which operates public transportation in and around Pittsburgh, approved cuts totaling 35 percent of its current service on Friday, according to a press release. These cuts, which will take effect on Sept. 2 of this year, will eliminate 46 of the 102 routes that ...
objects.title: Port Authority approves drastic cuts to service

objects.blurb: University of Pittsburgh senior Mike Rosenfeld was evacuated from classes five times during the past semester by bomb threats, but on Sunday he sat in his cap and gown in the bright sunshine outside of the Petersen Events Center with high hopes that his graduation ceremony would not be interrupted by yet another threat. His hopes were fulfilled when the ...
objects.title: University of Pittsburgh graduation goes smoothly

objects.blurb: A human clinical trial under way at UPMC's Hillman Cancer Center in Shadyside will help determine whether a combination of approved drugs based on a new theory of cancer can "revolutionize cancer therapy." That's the explanation of lead researcher Michael T. Lotze, who says his team has combined interleukin 2 (IL-2) with hydroxychloroquine in a new therapy designed to be ...
objects.title: Pitt aims to prove therapy can offer new cancer hope

objects.blurb: The classics, German and religious studies still will be taught at the University of Pittsburgh, but some graduate students in those departments are feeling as if they are part of an endangered species. The University of Pittsburgh has suspended admission to the graduate programs in the three departments. Admission offers already accepted will be honored. Current students will be able ...
objects.title: Pitt suspends some areas of study to save money

objects.blurb: The board of Pittsburgh Public Schools has delayed putting the historic former Pittsburgh Schenley High School building in Oakland up for sale. At its legislative meeting, the board voted 5-4 to table the motion to accept bids on the school up to June 29. Board members wanted to further explore whether the district could retain use of the addition -- ...
objects.title: City school board delays sale of Schenley High School building

objects.blurb: Pittsburgh City Council today is scheduled to take a final vote on a plan that will guide Carnegie Mellon University's development for the next 10 years, an effort involving hundreds of millions of dollars in investment. "The economic impact of CMU is felt throughout Western Pennsylvania," Councilman Bill Peduto said Tuesday, after a gathering with university officials to highlight the ...
objects.title: CMU presents 10-year plan to city
